Article.Abstract: To identify Mycobacterium leprae-specific human T-cell epitopes, which could be used to distinguish exposure to M. leprae from exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis or to environmental mycobacteria or from immune responses following Mycobacterium bovis BCG vaccination, 15-mer synthetic peptides were synthesized based on data from the M. leprae genome, each peptide containing three or more predicted HLA-DR binding motifs. Eighty-one peptides from 33 genes were tested for their ability to induce T-cell responses, using peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) from tuberculoid leprosy patients (n = 59) and healthy leprosy contacts (n = 53) from Brazil, Ethiopia, Nepal, and Pakistan and 20 United Kingdom blood bank donors. Gamma interferon (IFN-gamma) secretion proved more sensitive for detection of PBMC responses to peptides than did lymphocyte proliferation. Many of the peptides giving the strongest responses in leprosy donors compared to subjects from the United Kingdom, where leprosy is not endemic, have identical, or almost identical, sequences in M. leprae and M. tuberculosis and would not be suitable as diagnostic tools. Most of the peptides recognized by United Kingdom donors showed promiscuous recognition by subjects expressing differing HLA-DR types. The majority of the novel T-cell epitopes identified came from proteins not previously recognized as immune targets, many of which are cytosolic enzymes. Fifteen of the tested peptides had > or =5 of 15 amino acid mismatches between the equivalent M. leprae and M. tuberculosis sequences; of these, eight gave specificities of > or =90% (percentage of United Kingdom donors who were nonresponders for IFN-gamma secretion), with sensitivities (percentage of responders) ranging from 19 to 47% for tuberculoid leprosy patients and 21 to 64% for healthy leprosy contacts. A pool of such peptides, formulated as a skin test reagent, could be used to monitor exposure to leprosy or as an aid to early diagnosis.
Article.ArticleTitle: A postgenomic approach to identification of Mycobacterium leprae-specific peptides as T-cell reagents.
Article.Affiliations: Immunology Unit, Department of Infectious and Tropical Diseases, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, London WC1E 7HT, United Kingdom. hazel.dockrell@lshtm.ac.uk.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This epitope has 7 out of 15 amino acid mismatches when compared to the sequence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, suggesting it's potential use as a Mycobacterium leprae specific diagnostic.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IFNg production by PBMC taken from nonexposed and noninfected healthy donors was not observed in response to epitope.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Documented exposure without evidence for disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No proliferation was observed in PBMC from leprosy exposed individuals when challenged with the epitope, however, 5% of PBMC from nonexposed and noninfected individuals did proliferate.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Documented exposure without evidence for disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IFNg production by PBMC was observed in response to epitope. 53% of leprosy exposed and 39% of infected individuals responded with more individuals from Ethiopia respoding than those from Nepal.

No proliferation was observed in PBMC from leprosy patients or leprosy exposed individuals when challenged with the epitope, however, 5% of PBMC from nonexposed and noninfected individuals did proliferate.
IFNg production by PBMC was observed in response to epitope. 53% of leprosy exposed and 39% of infected individuals responded with more individuals from Ethiopia respoding than those from Nepal.
5% of PBMC from nonexposed and noninfected individuals proliferated in the presence of epitope, however, no proliferation was observed in PBMC from leprosy patients or contacts.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This sequence was Identified as Rec A protein by an NCBI search. This epitope has 9 out of 15 amino acid mismatches when compared to the sequence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, suggesting it's potential use as a Mycobacterium leprae specific diagnostic.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: 10% of PBMC from nonexposed and noninfected individuals proliferated in the presence of the epitope. 10% proliferation was also observed in PBMC from leprosy patients or contacts.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Documented exposure without evidence for disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Proliferation was observed in 10% of PBMC from leprosy exposed individuals in the presence of the epitope, however, 10% of PBMC from nonexposed and noninfected individuals also proliferated.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Documented exposure without evidence for disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IFNg production by PBMC was observed in response to epitope. 64% of leprosy exposed and 47% of leprosy infected individuals responded.
IFNg production by PBMC taken from nonexposed and noninfected healthy donors was observed in 5% of the subjects in response to epitope.

Proliferation was observed in 10% of PBMC from leprosy patients or leprosy exposed individuals in the presence of the epitope, however, 10% of PBMC from nonexposed and noninfected individuals also proliferated.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This epitope has 8 out of 15 amino acid mismatches when compared to the sequence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, suggesting it's potential use as a Mycobacterium leprae specific diagnostic.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Documented exposure without evidence for disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Proliferation was observed in 16% of PBMC from leprosy exposed individuals in the presence of the epitope with 5% of PBMC from nonexposed and noninfected individuals proliferating.
5% of PBMC from nonexposed and noninfected individuals proliferated when challenged with the epitope, while 16% of PBMC from leprosy patients or leprosy exposed individuals proliferated.

Proliferation was observed in 16% of PBMC from leprosy patients or leprosy exposed individuals in the presence of the epitope with 5% of PBMC from nonexposed and noninfected individuals proliferating.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Documented exposure without evidence for disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IFNg production by PBMC was observed in response to epitope. 55% of leprosy exposed and 26% of infected individuals responded with more individuals from Brazil respoding than those from Nepal.

IFNg production by 5% of PBMC taken from nonexposed and noninfected healthy donors was observed in response to epitope.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Although this epitope has 7 out of 15 amino acid mismatches when compared to the sequence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, it's potential use as a Mycobacterium leprae specific diagnostic was found to be limited.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Proliferation was observed in 19% of PBMC from leprosy patients or leprosy exposed individuals in the presence of the epitope, however, 15% of PBMC from nonexposed and noninfected individuals also proliferated.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IFNg production by PBMC was observed in response to epitope. 52% of leprosy exposed and 37% of leprosy infected individuals responded with more individuals from Brazil respoding than those from Nepal. Six out of 11 of the responders and 5 out of 9 of the nonresponders had the predicted binding alleles of DR 1, 4, or 7.
